messageBody:
Dianne, thanks for your input.

The scenario you listed is very impressive. Also I learned something
from your ideas of pusurading Project/Product manager save some time
for writing Testing code.

Cheers,
- Frank

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, didoss@... wrote:
>
> I think it ultimately comes down to a question of faith. I truly
believe that the time I spend working on unit tests of my commercial
application saves me time on the other end. I can spend an extra
couple of hours writing some tests during my development, in order to
save my team quite a bit of effort down the road,...take this scenario,...
>
> I spend a couple incremental hours writing tests while I develop my
code;
> We run a nightly build;
> One morning I see that a test has failed;
> I spend an hour to fix it;
> It makes it to QC and our customer without further incident.
>
> OR
>
> I save a couple hours during development and don't write tests for
my code;
> The code gets built and released to our QC department;
> They spend a week testing the code, and then find the bug;
> I spend an hour to fix it;
> The code gets built and released to our QC department;
> They start over, with the schedule slipped a week.
>
> OR
>
> Same scenario, except that QC doesn't catch it - the customer does;
> we lose face with the customer;
> we repeat the full cycle to release, with the schedule slipped by
however long it took to get to the client.
>
> It is something that you have to sell to product management,...if
you can schedule time for writing tests (and writing before/during
development is less time than after the code is written), and schedule
time to fix bugs correctly (and write/fix tests to make sure it
doesn't get through again), then you can make your commitments to your
clients while providing a quality product that your staff can be proud of.
>
>
> my two cents,
> Dianne
>
> -------------- Original message --------------
> From: "frank zou" <frankz1998@...>
>
> Hi all,
>
> After lots of reading and trying, I think I understand the following
> benefits that Junit-base testing can give us:
>
> * more robust system
> * clean / good design
> * less regression bugs
> * confidence to do refactorying, especially at the later phase of the
> project.
> * and lots more...
>
> These are really good things, for open-source projects where there is
> no deadline pressure and resource could almost be thought as
> un-limitted. However, for commercial software development, is this
> still possible ?
>
>
> Although I knew JUnit and other JUnit-based open-source tools for a
> couple of years, my company and team never really enbrace it. The
> major reason is Product Managers always want to add cool features to
> the system quickly while programmers find the schedule is always too
> tight to spend any extra time to write testing.
>
> I know from the mail list and books that we can take lots of advantage
> of JUnit-based testing, I myself have no real hands-on experience on
> it. So here are my questions:
>
> * Will Junit-based testing make the project time longer or shorter ?
> Any hard statistic data ? ( Here I mean commercial project rather than
> open-source project. )
>
> * One intersting point I found is that after Junit-based testing is
> introduced, programmers tend to use IDE debugger much less than
> before. This would save lots of time. Is that true ?
>
> * Some guys say JUnit is good for biz / util code testing. But for web
> application development, where HTML/javascript would be root cause of
> lots of bugs, Junit is not so powerful. Any comments ?
>
> * How can I convince managers and programmers that JUnit-based is
> really possible for commercial software development ? Any differnece
> from open-source projects ?
>
>
>
> Can some Junit gurus shed some light here ?
>
> Thanks,
> - Frank
